Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2013 06:05AM jbokland wrote: Just had my BMX ON Dec 23.with TE insertion. Went to sleep with 36DD and woke with some little mounds and 3 drains Recovery not horrible, but was having some wild gastric reflux and spasms!!! Also, doc had me new a nasal wash/swab with Betadine pre_op.   Anyone else do that? ,,
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2014 06:48AM jbokland wrote: I, too, am having my 4th DD AC treatment on Thursday and then on to the 12 weeks of Taxol.  I will be very happy to look up at the IV pole and see the last bag of the red devil.  I read a nice and comforting note from another survivor on another board where she said that last year, she wanted to quit after her 3rd AC treatment and the doctor assured her she would muscle through; and she did.   I cried when I read it, because that thought has crossed my mind more than once. I was complaining of a LOT of tenderness and pain in my feet.  I was worried it was a neuropathy but the doc feels it is foot and hand....much better news!  I've not heard of anyone else metioning that issue. My goal on fills will be a C cup, about 650cc.  So my right will need to be 850 to accomodate for radiation and 750 on the left.....yeech.  I SO look forward sleeping well.
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2014 02:38PM jbokland wrote: Bravo ladies....we all have our unique perspectives on what and why we do what we do! I too was a 36DD on my 5'2" frame.   Large dents in my shoulders, painful changes in breast tissue during PMS that blew me up to a DDD.  Slept with a bra on for the last 25 years.  Everyone new me for my big boobs and bright platiunm hair...now they are both gone! Interesting...my PS office staff that fill me each week keep encouraging me to go larger that I envision.  They keep reminding me the exchange will leave me a bit smaller that the tissue expanders. (currently up to 650cc).  I think I will leave it as the 650 as my final exchange size.  I too love wearing thin strapped sundresses without looking like a hooker stuffed like a sausage!
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2013 10:25PM jbokland wrote: Nerve zingers! I like that description; I've been trying to explain them as hot poker's.  I've have been documenting and blogging my experience, including pictures.  I took pictures of my 3 day post_operative self.  I told friends on Facebook to let me know if they wanted to see and I would send them one; many did.   I even published an obituary for my boobs as one of the blogs.  Writing is a great comfort!
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2013 08:45PM jbokland wrote: I had my Bmx on 12/23.  Doc recommended I sleep in a recliner.  I had to buy one ( found a love seat theater-style). We took our bed down for while and my partner sleeps right next to me!  Sleeping quite comfortably.  I've only used 9 of the 50 percocets and I'm maintaining on 600mg of Advil every six.
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2013 05:40AM jbokland wrote: Bobogirl,  I am 7 days post Bmx and TE, 2 grenades still dangling at my waist.    So sorry for your setback and wish you well. Hope you can get home ASAP!

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2014 06:49PM jbokland wrote: Eve (Momaton), Hello from Orlando, BTW. I had nerve pain along the back of my arm and armpit after the lymph node removal.  Skin felt raw and burned and was worse than the post-op pain of the BMX I used a fantastic cream an herbalist made for me, a concoction of St. John's Wart infused EVOO, Aloe Vera, Lavender and other organic ingredients.- Felt better within a day!

Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2014 04:03PM jbokland wrote: Yes!   I went to a local costume and wig shop that caters to drag queens.  Got some good lessons but the real tip is is practice practice.  It takes practice!  Nothing like trying to get ready and sweating your ass off fighting with these things!  What I learned was to apply eyeliner first. Also, eyeliners will slide odd into your eye without the eyelashes to stop it,,, it stayed better if I used a base of powder shadow. ( I used a natural color , as I normally do t wear shadow. )    Apply glue along falsie and let it dried 20 secs or so. I close my eye half way and pull the outer corner ever do slightly taught.  I bought all kinds of brands.  Didn't have to spend a lot. ($4 avg)   I also learned to pick out ones with a solid lash base that looks like a continuos line.  Check out YouTube videos too!

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2014 07:52PM jbokland wrote: I know most of us are past the bald stage, but I have to share with you: When I was bald, I started 'bedazzling' my head. I just couldn't be comfortable in a wig and I preferred to go topless, but was a bit shy about it. It was SO wonderful to decorate my head and have people stop me to chat instead of give me that sympathetic half-smile and a nod. I could not get through a shopping area or public place without being stopped or complimented . More importantly, I was having wonderful conversations with people about their stories, their cancer experience. It made me proud and confident. Anyway, through lots of encouragement, I launched my own product and I call it Sassy Head. I only have one design now, but I REALLY need some people to give it a test spin for me. It works wonderfully on my skin ( I could sleep in mine and get 2-3 days use) but everyone is different. I have a very simple website (not pretty, but it works) if you would like to try one out. I am selling these for $8.00, but if you use the dropdown next to word Standard and select BCO, it will give you a price of just $2.00 (plus 3.00 for shipping). Below are some pics. The first group was my head when I was bedazzling, and the second is my available design. I plan to do additional designs, including a pink ribbon and designs for children. Your suggestions are welcome! www.sassyhead.com

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2014 11:04AM jbokland wrote: Notbuyingit-  I don't see hair loss (alopecia) listed as a side effect with this drug. FYI- I work for Micromedex, the drug and disease database that hospitals and doctors use to get all of their online information.  Its kind of like the Consumer Reports of drug and disease information.  We review all the information and studies and report out an unbiased, evidenced based information.  The FDA and Medicare use our data for their decision making on drugs as well.    I'll be happy to look up any other info!

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2014 01:42PM jbokland wrote: Meetoo....keep you expectations in perspective.  Nioxin and other shampoos/treatments are designed to create the best environment for the hair to regrow...as opposed to actually causing hair growth.  I used the scalp treatment and my hair grew in nicely (so far) but I honestly have no way to know if it would have done the same without the $25.00 bottle!

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2014 07:33AM jbokland wrote: welcome Coco! I had a different Chemo regime...I knew I would loose all my hair and just shaved it off when it started to leave me.  I did not wear a wig, I mostly went commando and decorated my head with bling....which I now have turned into my own designs and a business. ( silver linings!) My best advice is to keep the hair casualties in perspective.  You are in the fight of your life and whatever happens with your hair in the long run is a small price.  Manage it with however you are the most comfortable and confident!  If you can muster up the attitude to have a little fun with a new fashion challenge...do it! Best wishes!

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2014 09:23AM - edited Nov 24, 2014 09:55AM by jbokland Dear LadyJ- You are tougher than you know! Your friends and family are so gracious with their love and kindness; they will literally carry you through each step. Keep you sense of humor. When the ONC tell you to loose a few pounds before you start this....DO IT! Walk and exercise, even when you think you are too tired. Take extraordinary good care of your skin...invest in those good facial products. There is no shame in napping. Be diligent about working on your range of motion after surgery. Don't freak out over every bout of gas, headache or other issue...not everything is the cancer. Document your journey through journaling and photos, it will remind you of how far you have come! Come to the realization that you will not be the same person in one year, stop being disappointed that your hair is not the same, your clothes hang different, you make those little groaning noised when you flop in a chair. YOU ARE ALIVE and need to look forward to meeting the new you. Don't waste a minute on worrying about tomorrow...it will rob you of your joy today and prevent you from being engaged with every precious moment of your life. PS. You will receive all kinds of articles and pieces of advice on home remedies and alternative methods. Sift through them , but icing your fingers and toes through Taxol will really help minimize the damage to your nails and hand and foot syndrome!
Posts.Title: A year after the diagnosis....Letter of Advice to Myself jbokland Carol99

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2014 07:20AM jbokland wrote: DiMcCleland- Breathe. The fog feeling is quite familiar. Have someone with you for every visit to help record the information you are given. My best advise is attitude is 80% of recovery....go kick some ass! Hugs
Posts.Title: A year after the diagnosis....Letter of Advice to Myself jbokland Carol99

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2014 01:16AM jbokland wrote: clarrn/ love the interior!  It really looks inviting! I just flew for the first time since November. I normally travel internationally for business so I am well seasoned. Today was Orlando to Denver.  I was a little nervous about my stamina but I went. Put on my little compression sleeve and even asked someone to help me put my bag in the overhead.  Done people took a double take at my excruciating short hair.  Bad weather forced us to pass over Denver and in Amarillo.  Checked into hotel late and dinner was a bag of veggie straws.  Ahh the glamorous life.  I'm exhausted but All in all it felt good to be traveling and beats the shit out of sitting in a barco lounger with chemo!!  Wish me luck. I'm interviewing for a new job within my company   I lost my old job when I was DX.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in April 2014 Kazzy115 Sunshine36

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2014 07:44AM jbokland wrote: I did the 4 DD AC then 12 Taxol.  Taxol much easier but the fatigue by treatment 7 kicked my ass!   I am about 17 day PFC and my nails are tender, not too bad. However, still retaining water with the left foot and ankle swollen. Finally took a water pill last night and was up all night peeing. Feel much lighter this AM!!! - anyone relate?

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2014 06:22PM jbokland wrote: ladies, I finished my AC and Taxol 20 week ordeal on Thursday. My hair started to grow about 4 weeks ago and it's good to have the chemo behind me. I am here to give you encouragement and to let you know you WILL get through this!  I also want to share that when  I was bald, I started 'bedazzling' my head. I just couldn't be comfortable in a wig and I preferred to go topless, but was a bit shy about it. It was SO wonderful to decorate my head and have people stop me to chat instead of give me that sympathetic half-smile and a nod. I could not get through a shopping area or public place without being stopped or complimented . More importantly, I was having wonderful conversations with people about their stories, their cancer experience. It made me proud and confident. Anyway, through lots of encouragement, I launched my own product and I call it Sassy Head. I only have one design now, but I REALLY need some people to give it a test spin for me. It works wonderfully on my skin ( I could sleep in mine and get 2-3 days use) but everyone is different. I have a very simple website (not pretty, but it works) if you would like to try one out. I am selling these for $8.00, but if you use the dropdown next to word Standard and select BCO, it will give you a price of just $2.00 (plus 3.00 for shipping). Below are some pics. The first group was my head when I was bedazzling, and the second is my available design. I plan to do additional designs, including a pink ribbon and designs for children. Your suggestions are welcome! www.sassyhead.com
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in April 2014 Kazzy115 Sunshine36
